title.value: Dance of the Neurons: Unraveling Sex from Brain Signals
title.justification: The title is explicitly stated at the beginning of the paper, indicating the core focus of the research on identifying sex from brain signals.
title.quote: Dance of the Neurons: Unraveling Sex from Brain Signals

extractions.description: This paper explores the capability of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to detect biological sex from EEG data, assessing the robustness and transferability of sex-related patterns across diverse datasets. The study highlights how EEG-derived sex patterns might confound machine learning analyses in mental health, suggesting implications for personalized interventions.

type.justification: The paper involves experimentation with CNNs on EEG datasets to detect sex patterns, suggesting an empirical approach.
type.quote: In this paper, we investigated the robustness and transferability of sex-related patterns in EEG data using a Convolutional neural network (CNN) trained on several corpora of EEG recordings.

name.justification: The paper utilizes EEG data to explore neural patterns related to sex, placing it within the field of neuroscience.
name.quote: Understanding the complex interplay between brain function and sex is vital to advancing mental health comprehension.

name.justification: The paper specifically focuses on using EEG recordings to discern patterns related to biological sex.
name.quote: We used three publicly available EEG datasets with different sample sizes and conditions to investigate the effect of sex on EEG signals.

name.justification: The research employs Convolutional Neural Networks, a machine learning technique, to analyze EEG data.
name.quote: Machine learning has become a powerful tool in deciphering intricate neurological phenomena.

name.justification: ShallowNet is explicitly mentioned as the model used for experiments to detect sex from EEG data.
name.quote: We used ShallowNet [16] as our model for all experiments, as it is a simple and efficient Convolutional Neural network (CNN) that can perform well on various EEG tasks.

is_contributed.justification: ShallowNet was used in the experiments but is not presented as a new contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We used ShallowNet [16] as our model for all experiments, as it is a simple and efficient Convolutional Neural network (CNN) that can perform well on various EEG tasks.

is_executed.justification: ShallowNet was implemented and executed in the experiments for EEG signal classification.
is_executed.quote: We implemented ShallowNet in BrainDecode and trained it using the AdamW optimizer.

is_compared.justification: ShallowNet's performance is compared to previous models and across multiple datasets.
is_compared.quote: In table 2, we compare our models with previous work on sex detection on the TUAB dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Deep learning with convolutional neural networks for eeg decoding and visualization
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper by Schirrmeister et al. is cited as the source for ShallowNet.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We used ShallowNet [16] as our model for all experiments.

name.justification: The NMT dataset is explicitly mentioned as one of the datasets used in the experiments.
name.quote: NMT (NUST-MH-TUKL EEG): This dataset contains 2, 417 recordings from healthy and pathological subjects.

referenced_paper_title.value: The NMT scalp eeg dataset: an open-source annotated dataset of healthy and pathological eeg recordings for predictive modeling
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper refers to a specific publication describing the NMT dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The nmt scalp eeg dataset: an open-source annotated dataset of healthy and pathological eeg recordings for predictive modeling.

name.value: TUAB (Temple University Hospital Abnormal EEG Corpus)
name.justification: TUAB is specifically identified as one of the datasets on which experiments were conducted.
name.quote: TUAB (Temple University Hospital Abnormal EEG Corpus): This dataset is a subset of the TUEG corpus.

aliases: Temple University Hospital Abnormal EEG Corpus

referenced_paper_title.value: Automated interpretation of abnormal adult electroencephalograms
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper describes TUAB in conjunction with a thesis by López, related to EEG interpretation.
referenced_paper_title.quote: S. López, I. Obeid, J. Picone, Automated interpretation of abnormal adult electroencephalograms, Ph.D. thesis, Temple University, 2017.

name.justification: TUEG is mentioned as a comprehensive EEG data corpus used in the study.
name.quote: TUEG (Temple University Hospital EEG Corpus): This dataset is a large open-source corpus of EEG data, containing over 69, 000 recordings from 14, 987 subjects.

referenced_paper_title.value: The temple university hospital eeg data corpus
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is cited along with a reference to a publication by Obeid and Picone.
referenced_paper_title.quote: I. Obeid, J. Picone, The temple university hospital eeg data corpus, Frontiers in neuroscience 10 (2016).

name.justification: BrainDecode was explicitly mentioned as the framework in which ShallowNet was implemented and tested.
name.quote: We implemented ShallowNet in BrainDecode and trained it using the AdamW optimizer.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper attributes BrainDecode usage to Gemein et al.'s work on EEG diagnostics with machine learning.
referenced_paper_title.quote: L. A. Gemein, R. T. Schirrmeister, P. Chrabąszcz, D. Wilson, J. Boedecker, A. Schulze-Bonhage, F. Hutter, T. Ball, Machine-learning-based diagnostics of eeg pathology.
